description:
'''Kendrick Lamar Duckworth''' (born June 17, 1987) is an American rapper, singer, songwriter and record producer. Regarded as [[Billboard and Vibe's 50 Greatest Rappers of All Time|one of the greatest rappers of all time]], he was awarded the 2018 [[Pulitzer Prize for Music]], becoming the first musician outside of the [[Classical music|classical]] and [[jazz]] genres to receive the award.

Born in [[Compton, California]], Lamar began releasing music under the stage name '''K.Dot''' while attending high school. He signed with [[Top Dawg Entertainment]] (TDE) in 2005 and co-founded the hip hop [[Supergroup (music)|supergroup]] [[Black Hippy]] there. Following the 2011 release of his [[Alternative hip hop|alternative rap]] debut album ''[[Section.80]]'', Lamar secured a joint contract with [[Dr. Dre]]'s [[Aftermath Entertainment]] and [[Interscope Records]]. He rose to prominence with his [[gangsta rap]]-influenced second album ''[[Good Kid, M.A.A.D City]]'' (2012), which became the [[Billboard 200#Most weeks on the chart|longest-charting hip hop studio album]] in [[Billboard 200|''Billboard'' 200]] history; ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' named it the greatest [[concept album]] of all time. In 2015, Lamar scored his first [[Billboard Hot 100|''Billboard'' Hot 100]] number-one single, after featuring on the remix of [[Taylor Swift]]'s "[[Bad Blood (Taylor Swift song)|Bad Blood]]", and released his third album, ''[[To Pimp a Butterfly]]'' (2015), which infused hip-hop with historical [[African-American music]] genres such as [[jazz]], [[funk]], and [[soul music|soul]], and became his first of six consecutive number-one albums on the ''Billboard'' 200.

Lamar's critical and commercial success continued with his [[Contemporary R&B|R&B]] and [[Pop music|pop]]-leaning fourth album ''[[Damn (album)|Damn]]'' (2017), yielding his second US number one single, "[[Humble (song)|Humble]]". He curated original songs for the [[Black Panther: The Album|soundtrack]] of the 2018 film ''[[Black Panther (film)|Black Panther]]'', earning a nomination for the [[Academy Award for Best Original Song]] for the US top ten single "[[All the Stars]]". His fifth album ''[[Mr. Morale & the Big Steppers]]'' (2022), delved into introspection and concluded his tenure with TDE and Aftermath. His [[Drakeâ€“Kendrick Lamar feud|2024 feud]] with [[Drake (musician)|Drake]] and sixth album ''[[GNX (album)|GNX]]'' (2024) spawned the US number-ones "[[Like That (Future, Metro Boomin and Kendrick Lamar song)|Like That]]", "[[Not Like Us]]", "[[Squabble Up]]" and "[[Luther (Kendrick Lamar song)|Luther]]" with the second winning a joint-record five [[Grammy Awards]], including [[Grammy Award for Song of the Year|Song of the Year]] and [[Grammy Award for Record of the Year|Record of the Year]], and the lattermost becoming Lamar's longest-charting number one song on the ''Billboard'' Hot 100, spending 13 weeks on top of the chart.

Lamar has received [[List of awards and nominations received by Kendrick Lamar|various accolades]], including 22 Grammy Awards ([[Grammy Award milestones#Most Grammys won by a rapper|the third-most won by a rapper]]), a [[Primetime Emmy Awards|Primetime Emmy Award]], a [[Brit Awards|Brit Award]], 5 [[American Music Awards]], 7 [[Billboard Music Awards|''Billboard'' Music Awards]], 11 [[MTV Video Music Awards]] (including 2 [[MTV Video Music Award for Video of the Year|Video of the Year]] wins), and a record 37 [[BET Hip Hop Awards]]. ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' listed him as one of the [[Time 100|100 most influential people in the world]] in 2016. Three of his works were included in ''[[Rolling Stone]]''{{'}}s 2020 revision of the [[Rolling Stone's 500 Greatest Albums of All Time|500 Greatest Albums of All Time]]. His [[Super Bowl LIX halftime show]] in 2025 broke [[List of most watched television broadcasts in the United States|viewership records]], with 133.5 million viewers domestically. Outside of music, Lamar co-founded the creative company [[PGLang]] and ventured into film with his longtime creative partner, [[Dave Free]].
